content.content: There is currently a discussion going on in MIP35 that would see maker lend assets purchased via the PSM to compound in order to gain some interest. I would posit that a better decision for maker to would be to try and get the USDC off of its books outright. so the TLDR of everything below is: auction off USDC to buyback MKR instead There are basically 3 motivations behind this in my mind:  In order for the PSM to do its job there needs to be sufficient room between the current liabilities and the line of the PSM.  As a result of this it seems maker is going to need to raise the line to infinity in order to ensure that there is sufficient headroom in the PSM.   Holding tons of USDC is not capital efficient bc of inflation associated with the USD.  solving this through lending via compound (or any other protocol) introduces even more counter-party risks that maker then needs to contend with.   There are counter party risks associated with USDC. (Not to mention the counter-party in question is your largest competitor)  However in order to be able to get the USDC that was purchased via the PSM off the books maker first needs to pay down it’s liabilities associated with the PSM. See this post explaining dai liabilities. Luckily the protocol has a large store of equity that it can use in order to do this. image1098×246 9.3 KB The surplus buffer. So what i would suggest, is that instead of storing ALL of this equity as DAI in the surplus buffer we can convert a portion of it into equity stored via USDC in the PSM. So how do we do this? Well first we need to decide the rate at which we want to pay down the liabilities of the PSM. This could be implemented in a number of ways, but i would suggest that we pay it down like interest (maybe call the rate tint). That is, the PSM would have some annualized percentage rate associated with it and that rate would be “payed” to reduce the protocol’s DAI liabilities.  As far as the technical implementation of how to pay i believe all that needs to be done is to increment the systems sin. This would mean that over time the system would accrue sin via the PSM and once that sin reached 50K dai it would be paid off via the system buffer just as it is today. Over time this would mean that the protocol would gather equity in the PSM, so once you have 10,000 USDC worth of equity stored there you should be able to kick a flap auction the same as you do today with DAI only this time you’re auctioning off USDC instead. The nice thing about this does not change the overall amount of MKR you’re buying back. This is because you don’t destroy any equity with this scheme you just change it’s storage medium. Downside is that it does have implications on how quickly you can store DAI in the stability buffer which is still important as DAI is the systems unit of account. I wanted to throw this idea out there before MIP35 got too far along as a potential alternative, so this post is a bit rushed. That said, What do people think?

content.content: Ok i have given all of this “write off rate” and “losses” business some thought. See these two comments:     latetot:  My main question is don’t you need to know the DAI/USDC rate to decide how much Dai surplus to write off as Sin?       alexis:  The issue by selling the Usdc for MKR or Dai is that you end up selling at a higher price than what you bought it.   So i think this question really boils down to how much did the protocol pay for this asset? Because we want to be sure that if the protocol is selling assets it sells them at greater than or equal to the cost it bought it at. I think the important thing to note before we try and address this is that all of the protocols accounts are settled in DAI it doesn’t care about the USD value of anything, so what we want to know is “how much dai did the protocol buy this asset for?” Knowing that allows us to set a price floor, and since the protocol is ostensibly selling these assets to maker holders by buying and burning MKR it probably doesn’t want to charge a large premium in this trade. That being the case, what we probably want to sell off the asset at cost.  To figure out what the cost, is you need to look at the balance sheet again and how it changes in a PSM trade. What you are looking for here is how much did the protocol’s liabilities change in the asset purchase. That is your cost. I believe this is what it looks like. PSM-Cost900×600 15.2 KB You have (1 DAI - the tin amount) going to the asset seller and the tin amount going to the stability buffer, so how much did the asset in question “cost” the protocol? It cost 1 DAI, so if your are trying to sell this asset at cost you need to ensure that you sell it for 1 DAI to balance the books. Thus, the “write-off rate” for 1 USDC should be 1 DAI bc that is what the protocol spent. One thing i want to point out about this trade is that MKR holders get paid here too. That is the amount going to the stability buffer. Now lets come back to this losses business specifically: “by selling Usdc for MKR or Dai is that you end up selling at a higher price than what you bought it.” This is capital gains/losses and you incur those when you trade one asset for another, so the first thing that i want to note in this is that this happens when the USDC is purchased for DAI and it is happening today with the PSM with or without the addition of this proposal. Now we know that USDC value != to DAI value so by buying 1 USDC for 1 DAI someone has to be losing in that trade there is just a question of who. Well we can probably presume that it is not the seller of the USDC bc that actor wouldn’t interact with the contract if it lost money on the deal. The maker holders get the tin amount on the trade so they don’t lose there either. Now your probably thinking that it is the protocol because it paid the 1 DAI for the 1 USDC in the first place right. Well I don’t think so. This is because the protocol doesn’t really care. Like I said its accounts are settled in DAI so whatever the USD value of DAI is kind of irrelevant to the protocol. It just paid 1 DAI for some asset and that is all that matters to it. So if the asset seller didn’t lose any money and the protocol didn’t lose any money and mkr didn’t lose any money who did? The DAI holders I believe. Their assets (DAI) are being diluted in the trade and that ultimately ends up paying the difference. That is why putting money in the PSM brings down the DAI price. At the end of the day though I think all of this losses business is completely irrelevant to this proposal and if we really want to wrangle with that it is an issue with the PSM itself not with selling the assets that were purchased by it.

The actual flapping usdc to buy MKR, is actually way more complicated at the end as what it sound as we need to touch the core system to introduce a flap on assert.     Andy_McCall:  USDC value != to DAI   I had another thought about it, what if instead of using the income to burn MKR we use then with the delegator to wipe off the PSM debt by increasing its Dai position and the usdc stays inside as buffer? The delegator is easy to change, it has been modelling for that. The benefit of it is that we don’t need to do any auction so its direct with no lose. While I am not too much in favour as I think it is better to use the income and wait until the usdc unwind by itself this solution is easy to do with little effort and with little risk as we are outside the core system.

content.content: Andy_McCall:  So if the asset seller didn’t lose any money and the protocol didn’t lose any money and mkr didn’t lose any money who did? The DAI holders I believe. I disagree with it, the dai holders don’t lose on it as it is dai is worse 1dollar. The holder can sell it at 1 or buy it at 1. which is the value of it. The looser here is the trader that switch assert to dai, the trader will pay a 0.1% fees on it which is actually very cheap for him as this decrease the volatility, the other looser is the protocol as it takes the risk of the opposite assert (usdc) for a little price but this position is compensated by a better value of the dai due to the 1:1 peg.

content.content: @SebVentures @Andy_McCall  I think sometimes there is a bit of confusion in the representation of “surplus buffer” in the t-account. I think the confusion may come from calling SB as if it was the bank capital (equity). SB and Equity are closely related, but not the same.
